According to chemistry professor Palli Thordarson, soap works well on COVID-19 and most viruses because the virus is a self-assembled nanoparticle in which the weakest link is the lipid (fatty) bilayer. “The soap dissolves the fat membrane and the virus falls apart like a house of cards and ‘dies’, or rather, we should say it becomes inactive as viruses aren’t really alive,” the professor said. Thordarson explained that while alcohol-based disinfectants have similar effects, they are not really quite as good as normal soap. “The antibacterial agents in these products don’t affect the virus structure much at all.” Soapy water is totally different, Thordarson said, because it “competes” with the lipids in the virus membrane. The soap is effective in dissolving the glue that holds the virus together. It also outcompetes the interactions between the virus and the skin surface because soap contains fat-like substances known as amphiphiles structurally similar to the lipids in the virus membrane. Most viruses consist of three key building blocks: RNA, proteins, and lipids. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) also recommends washing hands with soap and water. “Hand washing reduces the amounts of all types of germs and chemicals on hands,” CDC said. Thordarson also reminded people to thoroughly rub and soak the hands. “The skin is quite rough and wrinkly which is why you do need a fair amount of rubbing and soaking to ensure the soap reaches every crook and cranny on the skin surface that could be hiding active viruses.” With that being said, you may now stop hoarding alcohol and start washing your hands with soap. Tags: ncov

title: Spraying alcohol all over your body to kill coronavirus and other myths
author: MYTH: Spraying alcohol or chlorine all over your body will kill COVID-19
text: As the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) continues to spread globally, news articles and social media posts about the outbreak continue to circulate online. Unfortunately, some information contains fiction — and during a viral outbreak, rumors and misinformation can be dangerous.  (Keith Bacongco / MANILA BULLETIN) MYTH: Spraying alcohol or chlorine all over your body will kill COVID-19 FACT: According to the World Health Organization (WHO), spraying alcohol or chlorine all over your body will not kill viruses that have already entered your body. “Spraying such substances can be harmful to clothes or mucous membranes (eyes, mouth). Be aware that both alcohol and chlorine can be useful to disinfect surfaces, but they need to be used under appropriate recommendations.” MYTH: Cold weather can kill COVID-19 FACT: There is no reason to believe that cold weather can kill COVID-19. The normal human body temperature remains 36.5C to 76C, regardless of external temperature or weather. MYTH: COVID-19 can be transmitted through mosquito bites FACT: The new coronavirus is a respiratory virus that spreads primarily through droplets generated when an infected person coughs or sneezes, or through droplets of saliva or discharge from the nose. To date, there has been no information or evidence that COVID-19 can be transmitted through mosquitoes. MYTH: Pets at home can spread COVID-19 FACT: The WHO reiterated that there is no evidence that companion animals or pets such as dogs or cats can be infected with the new coronavirus. MYTH: Vaccines against pneumonia can protect you against COVID-19 FACT: Vaccines against pneumonia, such as pneumococcal vaccine and haemophilus influenza type B (Hib) vaccine, do not provide protection against the new coronavirus. “The virus is so new and different that it needs its own vaccine. Researchers are trying to develop a vaccine against COVID-19, and WHO is supporting their efforts.” MYTH: COVID-19 only affects old people FACT: WHO underscored that people of all ages can be infected by the new coronavirus (SARS-CoV-2). Older people, and people with pre-existing medical conditions (such as asthma, diabetes, heart disease) appear to be more vulnerable to becoming severely ill with the virus. MYTH: Antibiotics prevent and treat COVID-19 FACT: Antibiotics only work against bacteria, not viruses. COVID-19 is a virus; therefore, antibiotics should not be used as a means of prevention or treatment. MYTH: There are medicines to prevent COVID-19 FACT: To date, there is no specific medicine recommended to prevent or treat COVID-19. “However, those infected with the virus should receive appropriate care to relieve and treat symptoms, and those with severe illness should receive optimized supportive care. Some specific treatments are under investigation, and will be tested through clinical trials,” the WHO noted. (Prepared by Gabriela Baron) Tags: ncov

title: Metro Manila under 30-day lockdown
author: By Argyll Geducos
text: By Argyll Geducos President Duterte Thursday night placed the entire Metro Manila under a 30-day community quarantine following the local transmission and the rapid increase of coronavirus disease (COVID-19) cases in the country.  (Photo courtesy of Sen. Bong Go / MANILA BULLETIN) In his address to the public following his meeting with the Inter-Agency Task Force for the Management of Emerging Infectious Disease, Duterte said domestic land, air, and sea travel to and from Metro Manila shall be suspended from March 15 to April 14. Duterte likewise told Metro Manila residents not fear the word “lockdown” since it is only implemented to keep them safe from the disease. “It’s just a matter of protecting and defending you from COVID-19. That’s about it. It has nothing to do with the power of the military or the police, nor my power or these guys beside me. It’s just an issue of protecting public interest,” he said. The President added that the public should not just brush the issue of COVID-19 aside. He, however, appealed for their cooperation. “It’s a serious one. It is true, ‘wag ninyong maliitin (do not belittle it). Do not minimize it. But as I said, do not kill yourself with worry because as I said, the government is doing everything to make it at least controllable,” he said. Public places He said mass gatherings, where the number of people attending could strain the planning and response resources of the community hosting the event, shall be prohibited during the community quarantine period. Mass public transports such as the Light Rail Transits (LRT), Metro Rail Transit (MRT), and the Philippine National Railways (PNR) shall continue their operations. The Department of Transportation shall issue guidelines to ensure social distancing in public transports. Class suspension Meanwhile, classes in all levels in Metro Manila shall remain until April 12, 2020 but all students are still required to fulfill their educational requirements during the period. Local government units, under the supervision of the Department of the Interior and Local Government (DILG), shall be responsible for implementing measures to ensure that students remain in their homes during the class suspension. President Duterte said students should stay at home and study but doubts they will follow his advice since he knows schoolchildren will just play with their phones. “Avoid trouble with the law, avoid trouble with anybody. Just follow. Better just stay home and study,” he said. “Kung ayaw niyong sundin (If you don’t want to follow), you stick with your cellphone, ang ga-graduate niyan yung cellphone niyo, hindi ikaw (your phones will be the ones graduating, not you),” he added. Localized community quarantines Meanwhile, Duterte laid down the guidelines local government units in other areas should follow in imposing localized community quarantines: Duterte left to the discretion of LGUs outside Metro Manila to suspend classes but warned they should not do so over trivial reasons. “It is only done because you have to protect them (students) from the COVID-19. ‘Yan lang talaga (That’s it). Do not do it just to please everybody,” he said. Work arrangement Work in the Executive Branch shall be suspended for the next 30 days without prejudice to the formation of skeletal workforces by government agencies to maintain the unimpeded delivery of services to the public. However, health and emergency frontline services shall remain in full operation. The private sector, on the other hand, is encouraged to implement flexible work arrangements following the guidelines that will be issued by the Departments of Labor and Employment (DOLE), and of Trade and Industry (DTI) for the welfare of workers. Meanwhile, all manufacturing, retail, and service establishments are advised to remain in full operation during the period of the community quarantine. However, they should implement strict social distancing measures. President Duterte said private company owners should make sure that their employees are taken care of if they would require them to come to work. “See to it that they are taken care of, ‘yang mga management, ‘wag ninyong pabayaan ang mga trabahante ninyo (the management, do not forsake your employees),” he said. The World Health Organization (WHO) has declared the COVID-19 a pandemic,  saying it was now a crisis that will touch every sector. The WHO pointed out that there were already 118,000 cases of the disease in over 110 countries Wednesday. READ MORE: World Health Organization describes coronavirus outbreak as pandemic WATCH  Tags: ncov

title: Ireland to shut schools, universities over coronavirus
author: By Reuters
text: By Reuters DUBLIN – Ireland will shut schools, universities, and childcare facilities until March 29 and restrict all indoor and outdoor mass gathering in response to the spread of the coronavirus, acting Prime Minister Leo Varadkar said on Thursday.  Ireland’s Prime Minister (Taoiseach) Leo Varadkar arrives for the second day of the European Union leaders summit, held to discuss the EU’s long-term budget for 2021-2027, in Brussels, Belgium, February 21, 2020. (Ludovic Marin/Pool via REUTERS/FILE PHOTO/MANILA BULLETIN) Ireland confirmed its first death of a patient diagnosed with the coronavirus on Wednesday as the number of confirmed cases of the virus rose to 43 from 34 a day earlier. There are also 18 cases in Northern Ireland, the British region which shares an open border with the Irish republic. “From 6 pm today, the following measures are being put in place and they will stay in place until March 29: schools, colleges and childcare facilities will close from tomorrow, where possible teaching will be done online or remotely,” Varadkar said in statement. “Our advice is that all indoor mass gatherings of more than 100 people and outdoor mass gatherings of more than 5,000 people should be canceled. You need to continue to go to work if you can, but where possible you should work from home.” Varadkar encouraged people to limit social interactions and for offices to stagger break times and hold meetings remotely to limit contact. While restaurants can stay open, they should look at how to operate social distancing, he added. Public transport will continue to operate and shops will remain open with plans in place to ensure supply chains will not be interrupted, he said. The announcement came after Dublin’s Mater Hospital, one of the capital’s main hospitals, postponed all outpatient appointments and elective surgeries until further notice on Thursday, saying the arrangements were necessary in order to deal with the impact of the virus. It said in a statement that staff across every part of the hospital “are working around the clock” to deal with the virus. “We’ve a duty as a society to protect ourselves, our parents and grandparents, our family and friends, our co-workers and neighbors,” Varadkar said in the statement which was broadcast on national television from Washington, where he is due to meet President Donald Trump on Thursday. “In the period ahead, the government will deploy all the resources we can muster. They are extensive but not unlimited. This is going to involve big changes in the way we live our lives and I know I’m asking people to make enormous sacrifices. Acting together as a nation, we can save many lives.” Tags: ncov

title: Singapore to close mosques to prevent coronavirus spread
author: By Reuters
text: By Reuters SINGAPORE – Singapore will close all mosques for at least five days for deep cleaning to prevent the spread of coronavirus after two congregants were thought to have been infected during an Islamic conference in neighboring Malaysia. The Islamic Religious Council of Singapore said the closures would take effect Friday, and that authorities are trying to track down around 90 Singaporeans who attended the three-day religious event in Malaysia’s capital Kuala Lumpur. Singapore’s health ministry said two of nine new cases announced on Thursday were of people who had attended the event, which has also been linked to at least 12 infections in Malaysia. A number of other religious groups have canceled physical gatherings in Singapore in recent weeks to try and halt the spread of a virus that has infected 187 people in the city-state. Tags: ncov

title: First death in Poland from COVID-19: deputy mayor
author: By Agence France-Presse
text: By Agence France-Presse Poland has recorded its first death from the novel coronavirus outbreak in the western city of Poznan, its deputy mayor said on Thursday. The 57-year-old female patient had been hospitalized in critical condition with pneumonia and “unfortunately she died not long ago,” Poznan Deputy Mayor Jedrzej Solarski told reporters. Poland currently has 46 other confirmed cases of coronavirus. READ MORE: World Health Organization describes coronavirus outbreak as pandemic   Tags: ncov

title: Oriental Mindoro remains COVID-19 free
author: By Jerry Alcayde
text: By Jerry Alcayde CALAPAN CITY, Oriental Mindoro – Governor Humerlito A. Dolor announced Thursday that there was no recorded case of coronavirus infection (COVID-19) in the province. Dolor said all precautionary measures to prevent the entry of the disease in the province were already in place and being undertaken, in close coordination with the Department of Health (DOH and other government agencies, to suppress and control its spread. Dolor said there is no ban on the entry of overseas Filipino workers (OFWs) returning home, but reminded them to strictly comply with the policies and protocols imposed by the government at airports and ports of arrival, particularly for those coming from countries with ongoing transmission of COVID-19, particularly China. The governor has also requested the returning OFWs to undergo the mandatory 14-day self-quarantine at their respective homes and avoid interacting with neighbors. The provincial government and the Philippine Ports Authority (PPA) have both installed thermal scanners at Calapan port and other major piers in the province. Trips from Batangas to Mindoro and from Dangay, Roxas in southern Mindoro to Caticlan where the prime tourist destination Boracay is located have not been suspended, Dolor said. Dolor has also appealed to his provincemates not to resort to panic buying as he dismissed reports that circulated in the social media that an NCOV-19 victim was monitored in Gloria town and Calapan. “It’s all fake news. We should not let ourselves be instrumental in the spread of baseless news. The best thing to do at this time is to wait or monitor the official announcement of the government thru the DOH,” said Gov. Dolor. In Roxas town, Mayor Leo G. Cusi, Sr. has ordered the suspension of all public activities and gatherings until such time that the presence of the threat and danger of NCOV-19 in the country is terminated. Cusi, likewise, created a local Task Force NCOV that will supervise the handling of any person under monitoring. The DOH has recently confirmed the death of a 67-year-old Filipina, the 35th recorded case of novel coronavirus. The World Health organization on Wednesday has declared the novel coronavirus outbreak a pandemic after it recorded deaths of 4,000 people and 118,000 cases worldwide. Tags: ncov

title: DOTr stepping up anti-COVID measures at offices, public transport
author: By Alexandria San Juan
text: By Alexandria San Juan While health authorities are urging the public to observe social distancing to prevent the spread of coronavirus disease (COVID-19) in the country, transport officials have stepped up its measures to assure the public of a safe mass transit system amid the rising number of cases of the disease.  Commuters donning face masks line up as they rush on to board the next passenger bus at Cubao, Quezon City  (ALVIN KASIBAN / MANILA BULLETIN) Transportation (DOTr) Secretary Arthur Tugade said the Department and its attached agencies are observing precautionary measures set by the World Health Organization (WHO) and the Department of Health (DOH) to contain the disease. “We ensure the riding public that we are doing measures to combat the spread of coronavirus in all transportation hubs. This will not stop us as a nation,” Tugade said in a statement on Thursday, adding that the disease should not hamper the usual operations of all sectors of transportation. According to Tugade, all personnel and stakeholders in the DOTr main office in Pampanga are required to undergo a temperature check before entering the office premises, and those with body temperature of 38 degrees Celsius and above will be redirected to the medical clinic. Apart from this, Tugade added that stakeholders and visitors must wear face masks and sanitize their hands upon entering the offices. The DOTr chief also directed all personnel on the frontline to maintain at least one-meter social distancing to limit potential exposure to the disease. Sanitizing public transport For the road sector, the Land Transportation Franchising and Regulatory Board conducted a spot inspection in various terminals in Quezon City to check the maintenance and cleanliness of facilities, and the availability of disinfectants and sanitizers which are free of use to passengers. The Land Transportation Office also ordered all its regional offices to ensure the availability of disinfectants and sanitizers, to be used by its employees and clients. Meanwhile, the country’s railway sector gave the assurance that all its train systems are being disinfected regularly. The DOTr said the Light Rail Transit (LRT) Lines 1 and 2, and the Metro Rail Transit Line 3 (MRT-3) are strictly implementing preventive measures and ensuring hygiene in its facilities. Self-quarantine Aside from these preventive measures, the agency said the Transportation secretary as well as other transport officials have taken the initiative to place themselves under self-quarantine, in observance of protocols set by the DOH. DOTr Assistant Secretary Goddes Hope Libiran told reporters that Tugade was exposed last week to a person who tested positive for the disease. In addition, Libiran said DOTr personnel who exhibit flu-like symptoms are being sent home. The DOTr has also started the temporary closure of some of its offices and agencies for cleaning and disinfection. Tags: ncov

title: Batanes gov’t imposes travel ban for tourists, non-residents amidst COVID-19 scare
author: By Jhon Ablat
text: By Jhon Ablat BATANES – The provincial government has imposed travel on tourists and non-residents and employees of the island as precautionary against the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) threat.  In the released advisory of the Provincial Information Desk, it said that Acting Governor Ignacio C. Villa has issued Executive Order no. 16, imposing the travel ban that will be effective from March 16 until April 16. Under this measure, all tourists and persons, who are not based in the province for residence and employment, will be prohibited to enter the island. While persons, upon the determination of the provincial Heath Officer, with official business in Batanes fulfilling his lawful obligation or addressing an urgent issue of national interest will be exempted with this restrictions. Moreover, local residents of Batanes will be allowed entry provided that they will present government-issued identification cards or documents stating their residence or employment within the province and will be subject to the latest quarantine procedures and other health protocols issued by the Department of Health (DOH). The authorities added that this procedure of isolation will not be lifted until the declaration for public health emergency has been terminated by the national government. On the other hand, the local government discourages local senior citizens, pregnant women, sick persons not needing urgent care or immediate referral and persons with non-communicable diseases such as diabetes, hypertension, cancer and the like to travel to the mainland Luzon. The authority also reminded the public to not panic, and to observed proper hygiene and coughing etiquette and to boost their immune system to fight the possible threat of COVID-19. They also prompted the community to avoid sharing fake information regarding the said issue. Tags: ncov

title: Calaguas group of islands, other tourist sites closed due to COVID-19 threat
author: By Jinky Tabor
text: By Jinky Tabor Vinzons, Camarines Norte – The Calaguas Group of islands and other tourist destinations in this town have been temporarily closed starting Thursday. An executive order signed by Vinzons Mayor Eleanor F. Segundo stated that the lockdown will be until March 25 as a precautionary measure against the spread of COVID-19. The local government’s Municipal Inter-Agency Task Force for the Management of Emerging Infectious diseases (MIATF-EID) recommended the said closure, The government is discouraging people from converging, and going to densely populated places which include tourist destinations. Calaguas Islands and other tourism spots here have been recording a significant influx of tourists both locals and foreigners. The Philippine National Police (PNP) was directed to conduct checkpoints in various entry points to ensure that no entry of tourists will be allowed while the Municipal Heath Office and the Municipal Disaster Risk reduction Management office will be on stand-by to address possible contingencies. Meanwhile, the Department of Tourism (DOT) Regional Director Benjamin Santiago said the decision of Vinson was in response to the government’s call for the safety of everyone. He said the operators and tourism offices can make use of the time to conduct improvement in the facilities and manpower of tourism establishments. Tags: ncov

title: Gensan mayor warns against disinformation drive amid COVID-19 threats
author: By Joseph Jubelag
text: By Joseph Jubelag GENERAL SANTOS CITY – Local authorities here have issued a warning against those who will engage in disinformation activities on social media regarding the spread of Corona Virus Diseases (Covid) in the city.  Mayor Ronnel Rivera(LGU Gensan / MANILA BULLETIN) In an executive order, City Mayor Ronnel Rivera said the city government will file appropriate criminal charges against those who would be found responsible for making or sharing false information on social media related to COVID-19 infection in the city which has been declared as COVID-free by health authorities. Rivera said local authorities have undertaken measures to counter the possible disinformation amid the declaration of public health emergency in the country brought about the threats of COVID infection which had taken a toll on some 40 patients afflicted with the virus in the country. “We warn those spoilers who engaged in disinformation to create panic among the public amid the COVID threats,” Rivera said. He stressed that the public should get the right information from local health authorities led by city health officer Rochelle Co who provides advisory on COVID updates. The mayor has also directed department stores and pharmacies to regulate the sale of alcohol, disinfectants and face masks to avoid possible hoarding. He also formed an inter-agency task force composed of police, military, Department of Health and Bureau of Quarantine to set up stringent checkpoints to check on the entry of motorists and passengers who show symptoms of COVID infection. The mayor has also directed concerned government agencies to implements stringent protocols for passengers and tourists arriving in the city’s airport and seaport. He has also ordered the cancellation and postponement of mass gatherings initiated by the city government. Tags: ncov

title: DOH reports 3 new cases of COVID-19; total cases in PH now 52
author: By MB Online
text: By MB Online The Department of Health (DOH) reported three new cases of coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) on Thursday, bringing the total number of confirmed cases in the country to 52. The health department also confirmed on Wednesday the second death in the country due to COVID-19. The number of cases across the globe has risen to more than 124,000 with 4,500 deaths, including a jump in fatalities particularly in Iran and Italy, according to an Agence France Presse tally. READ MORE: World Health Organization describes coronavirus outbreak as pandemic (Note: This is a developing story.) Tags: ncov

title: 6,000 UP-developed COVID-19 test kits now in stock
author: By Ellalyn de Vera-Ruiz
text: By Ellalyn de Vera-Ruiz Some 6,000 coronavirus detection kits developed by University of the Philippines (UP) scientists are now in stock, UP President Danilo Concepcion said Friday. The SARS COV-2 detection kit being manufactured and stockpiled by Manila HealthTek, Inc. as the GenAmplify COVID-19 detection kit will cost around P1,320 per test, in contrast to the foreign kit which costs around P8,500 per test.  A Manila Healthek Inc. staff shows the COVID-19 test kit developed by experts from the Philippine Genome Center and the National Institute of Health of the University of the Philippines- Manila at a press conference at the University of the Philippines Diliman yesterday. The kit, which was recently allowed by the Food and Drug Administration (FDA), is aimed to rapidly detect the presence of the coronavirus in an individual. (ALVIN KASIBAN / MANILA BULLETIN) “Around 200 GenAmplify™ kits can be produced in a week, and enough kits are in stock now for around 6,000 tests, with more orders for around 20,000 tests already expected,” Concepcion said. The detection kit was developed by UP Philippine Genome Center (PGC) Deputy Director Dr. Raul Destura and other scientists and researchers from the UP Manila National Institutes of Health and the PGC. It was funded by the Department of Science and Technology through its Philippine Council for Health Research and Development. Destura said countries all over the world have the “same starting point” and “same timeline” in developing specific diagnostic kits for COVID-19. This was after China made the genome sequencing of novel coronavirus publicly available last Jan. 12. “We have the responsibility to help the government in providing technology for the country. It was not easy but we did our best because we want to show (other countries) that we can also do it here to address the needs of our country,” Destura said. “We are one with the government in providing this technology to make it accessible to all.” “We just need two to three weeks of field validation for the testing kit to be released to a full commercial platform. We just need a little patience. Our main intention is public safety and service to the community and our country,” he explained. Concepcion said the Food and Drug Administration’s (FDA) issuance of a certificate of exemption for the kit will ensure that the locally produced technology will be made available to a greater number of Filipinos at much less cost. “With the increased availability of testing, we can expect that the number of confirmed cases of COVID-19 will likely grow in our country and perhaps in our university community. This might become a source of anxiety and concern, even fear,” he said. “However, we assure you that the UP administration is taking immediate and appropriate action in response to this outbreak, with the guidance of our experts from the PGC, PGH (Philippine General Hospital), and UP Manila.” Concepcion said the PGH has protocols in place to respond to the possible increase in the number of patients infected through local transmission. This includes the setting up of a hospital response to assure the readiness and safety of health staff to triage, diagnose, and manage patients suspected and confirmed to have COVID-19, including the creation of an incident command system or COVID task force. He added that they will be training front-liners and paramedical staff to address technical proficiency and emotional/occupational concerns related to COVID-19. They will also disseminate information and communicate risks about COVID-19 to the members of the UP community and the public, and prepare the public for COVID-19 through public education. Tags: ncov

title: DepEd to ‘protect everyone’ amid COVID-19 threat
author: By Merlina Hernando-Malipot
text: By Merlina Hernando-Malipot The Department of Education (DepEd) on Thursday said it is doing its best to “protect” everyone — officials, teachers, personnel, and learners alike — as the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) situation in the country and across the world continues to escalate.  (MANILA BULLETIN) “We are protecting everyone,” said DepEd Undersecretary and Spokesperson Nepomuceno Malaluan when asked about the status of teachers when classes are declared suspended. Teachers Dignity Coalition (TDC) National Chairperson Benjo Basas, in a separate statement also issued on Thursday, reiterated the group’s appeal for DepEd to clarify whether teachers are “obliged” to report for duty when classes are suspended or not. Based on the provision of DepEd Order No. 43, s. 2012, Basas noted that teachers are not required to report for work when classes are cancelled. The provision specifically cites that “teaching personnel handling cancelled or suspended classes are likewise allowed to leave their stations in consideration of the work they will need to undertake during make-up classes.” “This is very clear but we don’t understand why some DepEd officials in the region and the principals in some schools do not recognize this directive and still require their teachers to report to school even when classes are suspended,” Basas said. Since the class suspension was announced early this week, Basas revealed that the TDC has been receiving reports from its chapter officials on the field that some school officials require teachers to go to school to perform clean-up activities and “disinfect” their respective classrooms. Basas noted that many regional officials initially required teachers to go to school during class suspension to do cleaning tasks. But when their attention to this was called out, these local DepEd officials pulled out their directives. “If we are protecting our learners, we need to protect our teachers too because if they get infected with the virus, they can pass this on to the learners and even their family members,” he said. Malaluan earlier noted that the “major disinfecting” related to COVID-19 is mainly being done by local government units (LGUs). However, he noted that “within the classroom, the person supervising the observance of the health precautions is the teacher” and this “includes minor disinfecting within classroom, such as commonly-held objects such door knobs, etc.” In response to TDC’s latest statement, Malaluan noted that “dichotomizing the DepEd community” and “divisive posturing” are not needed “at this time of great need.” Tags: ncov

title: DTI 8 imposes 60-day price freeze on basic goods in Eastern Visayas
author: By Marie Tonette Marticio
text: By Marie Tonette Marticio  TACLOBAN – Following the issuance of Proclamation No. 922 declaring a State of Public Health Emergency throughout the Philippines due to the outbreak of coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19), the Department of Trade and Industry (DTI) in Eastern Visayas has imposed price freeze in all basic necessities for 60 days. Based on the latest monitoring of DTI 8 provincial offices last March 10, there was still adequate supply of alcohol, while some supermarkets and groceries have also limited the purchase to two bottles per customer. It also revealed that N95 and surgical masks were already out of stock. “The public is advised to refrain from panic buying and hoarding of alcohols, tissues, masks and other consumer goods,” Anthea Arvi Bobon, DTI 8 information officer said in a statement. DTI 8 likewise urged consumers to be vigilant in purchasing goods at its prevailing prices, and avoid patronizing retailers selling overpriced medical supplies such as alcohol and masks. It added that it remains committed to regularly monitor and exert efforts in ensuring that supplies are available for the public. According to Trade Secretary Mon Lopez, a local manufacturer has committed to make 1.6 million masks per month, and frontline services in the health sector will be given priority in the distribution of this supply. Tags: ncov

title: Angono to go after netizens posting fake news about COVID-19
author: By Nel Andrade
text: By Nel Andrade ANGONO, Rizal – The local government here has created a task force that will go after netizens sowing panic by posting fake news about the coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19). Mayor Jeri Mae Calderon has issued Executive Order No. 2020-13 establishing the Task Force On Proliferation of Fake News and False Information concerning the COVID-19 in the municipality.  Police auhtorities in Angono warn two netizens for spreading fake news about COVID-19.(Angono PIO / MANILA BULLETIN) The task force, headed by the Angono Chief of Police Lt. Col. Rodolfo Santiago II, Miguel Carlo Villamayor, municipal legal officer; Erwin John Robles, information system researcher; Clodualdo Alan Maniaol, acting municipal administrator; and Elida Bianca Marcial, community affairs assistant of the municipal government. Calderon said the primary function of the task force shall be the monitoring and identifying the person or persons involved in the dissemination and proliferation of fake news and false information relative to the COVID-19 and to arrest and prosecute those involved in the said illegal activity. The office of Calderon said the local chief executive was compelled to issue the executive order after a post of a screenshot that said that a COVID-19 patient was in a subdivision here, went viral on social media last March 11. Another post also claimed that a family was brought to Rizal Provincial Hospital-Angono, and several students reportedly being monitored of the virus. All of those information were false and considered fake according to the municipal government. Calderon encouraged netizens to verify information that they have been getting from the social media sites, with the Department of Health (DOH) and the official social media page of the municipal government before they share such information online or off line. Meanwhile schools will have more time for sanitizing their respective premises and take preventive measures to stop the spread of COVID-19 in the province as Rizal Governor Rebecca ‘Nini’ Ynares has declared suspension of classes in both public and private schools in the province until March 19. The class suspension also aims to minimize the movement of students and school personnel hoping to prevent spreading the disease in the province. In Antipolo, the COVID-19 pandemic has resulted in the residents scampering for alcohol in groceries and drug stores. It was learned that a prominent drug store in the Antipolo Poblacion ran out of supply of rubbing alcohol since Wednesday night. The branch hopes to replenish its stock of the much needed sanitizing agent reportedly by Friday or Saturday. Other mini groceries and stores in the city proper also had the same situation as of Thursday afternoon. Tags: ncov

title: Rockwell confirms 2 residents are positive for COVID-19
author: By Richa Noriega
text: By Richa Noriega Rockwell Land Corporation confirmed on Thursday that there are two residents who tested positive for coronavirus disease (COVID-19) in Joya North Tower, Rockwell Center, Makati.  Rockwell said one of the residents is now under the care of a hospital, while the other two members of the family are now on self-quarantine. “We are currently reaching out to those we determined to have come in close contact with the residents so as to inform them of the necessary precautionary measures to consider,” Rockwell said in a statement. The corporation said they completely disinfect the areas and reduce close contact scenarios between residents and guests. All public areas such as lobbies, elevators, and parking areas will continue to undergo daily periodic sanitation, it added. Rockwell underscored that they put in place safety protocols for the welfare of everyone in the community. “We encourage everyone to do their part in being conscious of possible exposure every time we meet people and go to public places,” the corporation said. Meanwhile, the Department of Health (DOH) announced on Wednesday the second death in the Philippines due to COVID-19. The health department also reported 16 new cases of COVID-19, bringing the total number of confirmed cases in the country to 49. READ MORE: World Health Organization describes coronavirus outbreak as pandemic Tags: ncov

title: VP’s office sanitized, closed for 2 days
author: By Raymund Antonio
text: By Raymund Antonio  Taking the necessary precautionary measures, the Office of the Vice President has disinfected its premises because of the threat from the coronavirus disease (COVID-19). The Quezon City Reception House, where Vice President Leni Robredo holds office, has been closed for two days, Wednesday and Thursday, to sanitize its facility amid the coronavirus concerns.  Vice President Leni Robredo (OVP / MANILA BULLETIN) Public events of Robredo were canceled, and OVP employees were allowed to work from home while total disinfection of their office was ongoing, according to the OVP. As of Wednesday, the number of confirmed cases of COVID-19 in the country rose to 49. The Department of Health (DOH) announced the first Filipino who died from the novel coronavirus. She was the 35th patient who was a 67-year-old woman with no travel history. The woman was admitted at the Manila Doctors Hospital after showing symptoms on February 29 and tested positive for the virus on March 11. Robredo gave reminders to the public on how to stay safe amid the increasing COVID-19 cases. “Huwag mag-panic. Makiisa sa kinauukulan para maging mas mabilis at epektibo ang contact tracing. Magbahagi lamang ng mga tamang impormasyon tungkol sa COVID-19 mula sa mga awtoridad (Don’t panic. Let us cooperate with authorities for faster and effective contact tracing. Share the right information from authorities about COVID-19),” she said in a Facebook post. The vice president cited readiness of the private sector to help the government in the mobilization of resources to solve the health issue. “Kung problema ang procurement, mag-issue ng kaukulang order para mabilis ang mga dapat bilhin. Kung budget ang problema, pagtulungan na natin. Mahalagang kumilos nang may malinaw na direksyon at istratehiya (If the problem is procurement, issue the necessary order to speed up the purchase of those needed. If the budget is the problem, let us work together. It is important to act with clear direction and strategy),” she said. To enable faster detection of COVID-19, Robredo underscored the need to expedite the production of the test kits developed by University of the Philippines (UP) scientists and distribute them in affected areas. To prevent the spread of the infection, she urged concerned agencies to intensify information campaign on how the people can protect themselves from COVID-19 such as observing proper hygiene and avoiding crowded places. Tags: ncov

title: Stern measures imposed in Cavite as more PUIs reported
author: By Anthony Giron
text: By Anthony Giron IMUS, Cavite — Authorities have imposed stern measures to fight the coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) in Cavite province as four more persons under investigation (PUIs) were reported in the area. In capital Imus City, the local government has called off all set programs, festivities and activities in the next 14 days, starting Wednesday, March 11, in the areas as one of the measures being undertaken against the CoVID-19. The first confirmed COVID positive case patient, a 48-year-old seaman, and two PUIs, including a woman, were reported in Imus. City Information Officer Edgardo Jay Saquilayan, also the designated Anti-COVID spokesman, said on Wednesday that all measures against the virus were being implemented, particularly in busy areas. The city government has called on all sectors to fight the virus with the measure implementation such as cleaning and sanitation and disinfection to kill the coronavirus. At the City Hall, the busiest public area, all entering persons have to undergo thermal scanning and hand washing with the provided alcohol and sanitizer at the lobby entrance. The city police station also put up a table with a big bottle of alcohol where they one wash their hands. Saquilayan said that the Social Distancing Policy particularly in public areas have been implemented as a prime measure against the CoVID-19. In his latest update, Governor Juanito Victor C. Remulla Jr.said that at least four PUIs, including a one-year-old baby from Tanza municipality, and a new patient from Noveleta municipality, are now being monitored by the local health officers. The baby had a recent travel history to Italy, a country that was reported hit hard by the COVID. Remulla was the first to announce on Tuesday the first COVID case in Imus and the other PUIs in the turf. In his update, Remulla also reported that with the contract tracing, 11 that are in contact with the first CoVID patient have also sought consultation in private hospitals in Cavite. Nine of the 11 contacts were declared asymptomatic, with one showing symptoms and is now under self-quarantine. Remulla confirmed that one remaining contact was admitted as a PUI in a private hospital in Imus after showing symptoms of COVID infection. The PUI boarded the same flight with the first confirmed patient in Imus. The governor also reported that the second PUI, the woman from South Korea, is still confined in another private hospital in Imus as authorities are waiting for test results from the Research Institute for Tropical Medicine (RITM) in Muntinlupa, Metro Manila. Remulla tagged as “false” the reports claiming that Imus was in lockdown due to the PUIs in the area. The new PUI in Noveleta, a woman, is still under observation in a hospital, also in Cavite. Her sample was taken and brought to RITM, according to Remulla. With his statement, the governor called on the citizens to observe the Social Distancing Policy and sanitation and report any individuals with cough, cold and flu. Remulla and Imus Mayor Emmanuel Leonardo Maliksi have been rendering pronouncements, advice, tips and actions daily through their Facebook accounts since the COVID alert was raised by the Department of Health. The Provincial Epidemiology Surveillance Unit (PESU) under Dr. Nelson Soriano reported earlier that there were 33 PUIs in Cavite in the last two weeks with some being cleared after observation and test results turned out negative. The PESU report relayed to the local health offices earlier said that there were eight PUIs in Dasmariñas City, five in Silang municipality, four in Imus and three in Bacoor City. Governor Remulla has suspended classes in all levels province-wide from March 10 to 14 to safeguard tens of thousands of students in the province’s eight districts. Tags: ncov

title: Bacolod declares state of local health emergency due to COVID-19 threat
author: By Glazyl Masculino
text: By Glazyl Masculino BACOLOD CITY – Members of the City Council unanimously approved a resolution on Wednesday, declaring a state of local health emergency here due to the coronavirus disease (COVID)-2019 threat in the country. Mayor Evelio Leonardia, in a press briefing on Thursday, said that the basis for the declaration was President Duterte’s Proclamation No. 922, declaring a state of national health emergency all over the country, and the World Health Organization (WHO) declaration that the disease was already a public health emergency of international concern. Leonardia said there was no need for him to issue an Executive Order because the resolution of the City Council and the position of the President were enough basis for the local declaration. For his part, Sangguniang Panlungsod (SP) majority floor leader Councilor Renecito Novero, who authored Resolution No. 282, said the declaration will enhance the city government’s preventive measures and justify the utilization of the calamity fund to battle the disease. The Bacolod City Disaster Risk Reduction and Management Council (CDRRMC) has passed a resolution last January, requesting for a P10-million budget that will be utilized by the inter-agency task force for the prevention and control of COVID-19. The resolution of the CDRRMC was already ratified by the SP. Meanwhile, Dr. Julius Drilon, medical chief of Corazon Locsin Montelibano Memorial Regional Hospital (CLMMRH) here, said that they already activated the emergency response mechanism. They were also continuously communicating with health providers to elevate their training in case there’s an increase of persons under investigation to be admitted in the hospital. Tags: ncov

title: Duterte Cabinet continues to function in wake of quarantines
author: By Genalyn Kabiling
text: By Genalyn Kabiling The Duterte Cabinet will continue to work and provide service even though some officials went on self-quarantine as a precaution against the coronavirus outbreak. Executive Secretary Salvador Medialdea assured the public that the Cabinet members would work and remain in contact through the country’s modern technology, even hold meetings via teleconferencing.  President Rodrigo Roa Duterte speaks with Executive Secretary Salvador Medialdea (RICHARD MADELO/Presidential Photo / MANILA BULLETIN) Medialdea is among the Cabinet officials who decided to go on self-quarantine amid concerns about a possible exposure to a  coronavirus case. “We just have to stay away from each other. Telepono na lang, text-text. Nagcre-create ng sistema ngayon na puwede kami mag-meet for teleconferencing. (We will remain in touch through telephones, text messaging. A system is being created to allow us to meet for teleconferencing),” he said in a phone interview with Palace reporters. To contain the spread of coronavirus, Medialdea admitted that the activities in the Palace have been reduced as part of social distancing measures. The Presidential Security Group earlier enforced stricter health protocols in the President’s events, including no touch policy and health screening of persons who will get near him. Large public events will also undergo PSG assessment if these will push through or not. “Yung mga movements lang ng mga tao siyempre you have to restrain some movements. Yung madaming activities syempre kaunti na lang ngayon kaysa nung dati (You have to restrain some movements of the people. There are fewer activities compared to the many activities before),” Medialdea said. Apart from Medialdea, Finance Secretary Carlos Dominguez III, Transportation Secretary Arthur Tugade, Public Works and Highways Secretary Mark Villar, and Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas (BSP) governor Benjamin Diokno have reportedly agreed to go on self-quarantine as a precaution against the virus. President Duterte, along with some cabinet members, attended an infrastructure-related event last March 5 where a person who reportedly tested positive for the coronavirus was reportedly also present. Medialdea admitted that he was present during the event but did not have close contact with the reported confirmed case. “Yung Thursday last week. I was there..si Tugade. si Sonny Sec Dominguez. Nandun siya and then wala naman contact na ano, dumaan lang sya, bumati sya, ganun lang (I was there last Thursday. Secretaries Tugade and Sonny Dominguez were also there . The person was there but we ddi not have close contact. He passed by and greeted us. That’s it),” he said. “May distance naman. Ako may distance kaming dalawa.siguro two or three meters, nagkawayan kang (There is distance. I was two or three meters away from him. We waved to each other),” he added. As a precaution, Medialdea said he has also advised his staff to undergo testing for coronavirus. Tags: ncov

title: Albay designates hotel as COVID-19 quarantine center
author: By Niño Luces
text: By Niño Luces LEGAZPI CITY, Albay – The Albay Public and Emergency Management Office (APSEMO) announced on Wednesday that the provincial government has designated Mayon Skyline Hotel as quarantine center for locals who need to be isolated because of the coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19). Located in Barangay Buang in Tabaco City, the former commercial hotel can accommodate at least more than 20 patients. APSEMO chief Dr. Cedric Daep said that trained medics will be assigned at the site located near Mayon Volcano. He said that this will be an additional quarantine facility in the province. Earlier, the Department of Health (DOH) Bicol said that Bicol Regional Training and Teaching Hospital (BRTTH) in Albay province, Bicol Medical Center (BMC) in Naga City and Bicol Sanitarium in Cabusao town, also in Camarines Sur. Meanwhile, according to DOH, as of Friday noon, Bicol still has no confirmed case of COVID-19, while all patients under investigations (PUIs) recorded have all been discharged. Tags: ncov

title: Classes, events in Albay suspended due to COVID-19
author: By Niño Luces
text: By Niño Luces LEGAZPI CITY, Albay – Classes in all levels, in both public and private schools in Sto. Domingo town, Albay province were suspended due to coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19). Mayor Jun Aguas issued an advisory on Thursday afternoon that classes will be suspended from March 13 to March 22 to avoid the spread of the virus. “Upang maiwasan ang paglaganap ng COVID-19, suspendido na ang lahat ng klase sa mga pribado at pampublikong paaralan sa lahat ng lebel sa buong bayan ng Sto. Domingo, Albay epektibo bukas, araw ng Biyernes hanggang Marso 22,” Aguas said in his advisory. Earlier, St. Agnes Academy in Legazpi City also suspend classes from March 13, to March 25 due to COVID-19. “In the midst of our growing concern over the fast spreading COVID-19, we, Sisters and Lay Administrators of St. Agnes Academy has decided to come up with precautionary measures to ensure the safety of our learners and personnel and other stakeholders. We decided to quarantine the Grades 11 and 12 HUMMS and teacher-chaperones who went to Manila and visited the Senate. They arrived safely and well early this morning. They are at home until the 25th of this month to fulfill the 14-day quarantine period as recommended by our school doctor and health officials. Cancel on-site classes from March 13 to 25th of March. Our teachers have prepared modules for learners and students to accomplish at home and to be submitted when they come back to school on March 26.,” the advisory said. The Genecom Institute of Technology, also in Legazpi City has also ended regular classes on March 13. In an advisory, Genecom said that the last day of regular class will be on March 13 to reduce exposure and heightened precautions. All related compliance such as submission of projects, special examinations, signing of clearance and other related matters shall be done with appointment with teachers concerned. Mayor Patricia Gonzalez-Alsua told the Manila Bulletin that some events during the annual celebration of Sunflower Festival were cancelled. Instead, a one-day event will be held on March 24, during the 19th Cityhood anniversary. Read more: Ligao City cuts short ‘Sunflower Festival’ due to COVID-19 Albay 2nd District Joey Salceda also announced the suspension of Albay 2D Congressional Cup Inter-Barangay Basketball Tournament starting Thursday night “until further notice” despite Albay Public Safety and Emergency Management Office (APSEMO) clearance to continue its actions. The Congressional Cup has 437 team-entries making it as the largest basketball league in the region. Tags: ncov

title: Big festivals in SOCCSKSARGEN cancelled amid COVID threat
author: By Joseph Jubelag
text: By Joseph Jubelag GENERAL SANTOS CITY- The threats posed by coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) have taken a toll on several big festivals in the SOCCSKSARGEN region which have been cancelled amid possible health risks during the festivities.  Seslong Festival(Facebook / MANILA BULLETIN) Local officials of T’boli. South Cotabato opted to cancel the ongoing events of this year’s Seslong Festival which kicked last March 5 until March 14 in compliance with the directive of Interior and Local Government Secretary Eduardo Ano who directed all local government units to cancel and postpone all events and activities that draw huge audience. T’boli Mayor Dibu Tuan issued an executive order which sought the cancellation of all scheduled activities during the 22nd Seslong Festival which is held in conjunction with the 46th founding anniversary of T’boli municipality. He said the local government was not taking any chances in pushing through with the festivities despite the stringent safety measures they have already undertaken to avoid COVID-19 infection during the celebration. Meanwhile, in Sarangani Province, Gov. Steve Solon also decided to cancel the holding of this year’s Sarangani Bay Festival slated in May amid the outbreak of the virus in the country. Solon said festival organizers of the Provincial Tourism Council recommended the cancellation of the festival which had been drawing some 100,000 local and foreign tourists who flock to one of the biggest bay festivals in the country. The governor said the provincial government considered the health of revelers as the fundamental and highest concerns to be protected amidst the worsening situation of the deadly coronavirus in the country following the recent declaration of President Duterte who placed the entire country under the state of public health emergency. Tags: ncov

title: South Africa reports first case of local transmission of coronavirus
author: By Reuters
text: By Reuters JOHANNESBURG – South Africa’s health ministry on Thursday reported the first case of local transmission of the coronavirus, saying a 32-year-old man had contracted it after coming into contact with a Chinese businessman. “All others (cases) have been by patients who had traveled abroad,” the ministry said in a statement, adding that the number of confirmed cases had risen to 17 from 13 on Wednesday. READ MORE: World Health Organization describes coronavirus outbreak as pandemic Tags: ncov

title: Tiangco to self-quarantine as precautionary measure, has no COVID-19 symptoms
author: By Joseph Pedrajas
text: By Joseph Pedrajas Navotas Mayor Toby Tiangco will undergo self-quarantine as a preventive measure against coronavirus disease (COVID-19), after learning that some Cabinet officials who attended an event he was also at have already done so.  Navotas Mayor Toby Tiangco (NAVOTAS PIO/ MANILA BULLETIN) Tiangco announced this Thursday morning, following the initiatives taken by some Cabinet officials including Executive Secretary Salvador Medialdea, Finance Secretary Carlos Dominguez, and Transportation Secretary Arthur Tugade, who previously attended an event that was also attended by a patient who tested positive for COVID-19. “Kaninang umaga pag-gising ko, nakita ko po sa news na ilang Cabinet secretaries ay nag-self quarantine dahil sila po ay pumunta sa isang affair na kung saan ang isang tao ay nag-test positive sa COVID-19,” he said. (When I woke up, I saw on the news that some Cabinet secretaries are under self-quarantine because they attended an affair where one person tested positive for COVID-19.) “Nakaharap ko rin po itong mga Cabinet secretaries na ito, kaya sa tingin ko ang tinutukoy na affair ay nandoon din ako,” he added. (I met with these Cabinet secretaries, so I think I also attended the affair that is being referred to.) However, Tiangco said he is not showing any signs of COVID-19 symptoms and will only undergo quarantine “for the safety of the people.” Tiangco is the second Metro Manila mayor to undergo self-quarantine amid the rising number of cases of COVID-19. On Wednesday evening, Manila Mayor Francisco “Isko Moreno” Domagoso already did the same after he returned from a trip to the United Kingdom. READ MORE: List: Gov’t officials on self-quarantine due to COVID-19 exposure Tags: ncov

title: Hontiveros warns water shortage a threat to COVID-19 response
author: By Hannah Torregoza
text: By Hannah Torregoza Senator Risa Hontiveros on Thursday warned that a water shortage, as the nation enters the dry season, would pose a big problem to the government’s efforts at battling COVID-19.  Senator Risa Hontiveros (JAY GANZON / MANILA BULLETIN) Hontiveros said the ongoing water shortage in Metro Manila is putting entire communities at grave risk, denying many Filipinos the ability to protect themselves against the COVID-19 outbreak. “Paano tayo maghuhugas ng kamay kung wala namang tubig (How are we going to wash our hands if there is no water)?” Hontiveros asked. The number of infected individuals who have contracted the severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2), the virus that causes the coronavirus disease-2019 (COVID-19), climbed to 49 cases as of last night. Against this backdrop, water concessionaires Manila Water Company and Maynilad Water Services has said they will implement rotational water service interruptions starting this month. Hontiveros said the supply interruptions will have a “severely disastrous effect” on efforts to contain the rapid spread of COVID-19 in the metro. “There is only one thing more important than face masks or alcohol in our fight to prevent the virus, and that is running water,” she said. “Proper hand washing with soap and running water is the most effective way to kill viruses and avoid getting infected.” “Kapag mahina ang tulo ng tubig, hihina din ang laban natin sa COVID-19. Nilalagay natin sa peligro ang mismong buhay at kalusugan ng ating mga kababayan, (If water flow is weak, our defense against COVID-19 will also weaken. We are putting the lives and health of our people at risk),” Hontiveros said. People living in poor and densely-populated communities where social distancing can be impossible are especially vulnerable, the senator said. Hontiveros then urged the government, especially the National Water Resources Board (NWRB) and the Metropolitan Waterworks Sewerage System (MWSS), to step up their efforts to boost the water supply in communities in the upcoming weeks. She said a steady water supply should be particularly provided to urban poor neighborhoods and areas where there is a heavy concentration of people. “Magpadala na po kayo ng water trucks, para kumpleto ang tulog ng mga tao, imbes na pumipila o naghihintay ng tulo ng gripo sa hating gabi o madaling araw, (Please start sending water trucks so people can sleep, instead of waiting for hours to wait for water to come),” she urged the water concessionaires. “We should not allow poor public services to worsen the already terrible COVID-19 outbreak into a deadly health crisis,” she said. Tags: ncov

title: Man, 53, tested positive for COVID-19 in Las Pinas
author: By Jean Fernando
text: By Jean Fernando The Las Pinas City government confirmed that a 53-year-old man confined at the Las Pinas General Hospital and Trauma Center tested positive for COVID-19. The Las City Public Information Chief, Jimi Castillano, said that the patient was found to have no history of travel abroad. Castillano said that Mayor Imelda Aguilar upon learning that there is a city resident tested positive for COVID-19 virus, immediately dispatched the surveillance team of the Las Pinas City Health Office to conduct contact 48 tracing of the family members of the patient and other persons whom he had contact with. He also said that the mayor also ordered the surveillance team to determine where the patient is living. The city government also created a COVID-19 operation center which will serve as help line and will monitor all persons with symptoms of the disease. The mayor told the city residents to call 8994-57-82/ 091561735 for Globe and 09284627034 for Smart number in case they known of any resident symptoms of the disease. Aguilar also told the city residents not to panic because the city government is following all the protocols set by the Department of Health (DOH) and the World Health Organization (WHO). Tags: ncov

title: DepED: Automatic passing of learners not an option
author: By Merlina Hernando-Malipot
text: By Merlina Hernando-Malipot Despite the escalating threat of the coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) in the country, the Department of Education (DepEd) maintained that mass promotion and automatic passing of learners will not be allowed or tolerated.  DepEd Sec. Leonor Briones (FEDERICO CRUZ / MANILA BULLETIN FILE PHOTO) Education Secretary Leonor Briones said that DepEd will not allow mass promotion or giving automatic passing grades to learners “because this is not the policy of the Duterte administration.” Earlier, various stakeholders have urged DepEd to give automatic passing grades to learners amid the continued threat of the COVID-19. Classes in Metro Manila and other areas where COVID-19 cases are confirmed have been suspended. Since the current school year is already about to end, DepEd was asked to consider the possibility of giving passing grades to learners – especially those who have missed out lessons in school. Read more: Navotas mayor asks DepEd to just grant all students passing grades for current school year However, Briones said that DepEd “strongly opposes” any move to allow mass promotion of students because the “the law is clear as to the number of days of face-to-face contact between teachers and students.” DepEd “might be held liable” if the number of school days mandated by law is violated, she said. Meanwhile, Undersecretary and Spokesperson Nepomuceno Malaluan said since the suspension of classes were declared when the current school year is almost over, teachers “have enough grades even in the absence of final grades.” DepEd has rescheduled the final examination dates of learners as required in the curriculum. “We’re still hoping that the [final] tests will be done but we have already outlined our plans in extreme cases or situation,” he added. Malaluan said that protocols related to COVID-19 “in all situations that will happen” are already in place. Under extreme situation like the Department of Health (DOH) declaring a higher alert public health status, he noted that the schools have “already a base to rate the students.” He added depending in the circumstances of the learners, providing remedial measures will also be arranged. Tags: ncov

title: China says peak of coronavirus epidemic has passed
author: By Reuters
text: By Reuters BEIJING – China has passed the peak of the coronavirus epidemic, the National Health Commission said on Thursday. The comments were made by commission spokesperson Mi Feng at a news conference. Tags: ncov

title: Ligao City cuts short ‘Sunflower Festival’ due to COVID-19
author: By Niño Luces
text: By Niño Luces LIGAO CITY, Albay – The local government of Ligao City in the province of Albay has cut short the annual celebration of Sunflower Festival this year.  Mayor Patricia Gonzalez-Alsua (2nd from right) during a meeting on COVID-19 at the Sangguniang Panlungsod Session Hall on March 11(City Government of Ligao / MANILA BULLETIN) Mayor Patricia Gonzales-Alsua said this is in response to the growing threat to public health and safety posed by the confirmed local transmission of coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) in the country, and subsequent Presidential Proclamation No. 922 declaring a State of Public Health Emergency throughout the Philippines, the supposed one-week celebration will only be held one day. Gonzales said that all events will be done during the 19th Cityhood Anniversary on March 24. These include the thanksgiving mass, a tree planting activity, job fair, raffle draw, blessing and opening of heritage library, ribbon cutting of science and technology showcase, eco-bag design painting contest, Sinrang Awarding ceremony and LGU night. “Ang mga events na ito ay pinili natin dahil hindi naman gaano kalaki ang mga crowds ng mga ito,” she said. Except for the 5th Sunflower Festival National Enduro Challenge, the event will push through on Sunday, March 15. “Yung Enduro Challenge naman ay may distansiya naman yung bawat isa and does not require a big crowd,” the mayor told the Manila Bulletin. Among the postponed events “until further notice” are the Color Run, concert of Michael Pangilinan, and Coastal Caravan. Tags: ncov

title: Kazakhstan suspends all public events over coronavirus
author: By Reuters
text: By Reuters ALMATY – Kazakhstan is suspending all public events and closing schools and colleges in response to the coronavirus outbreak, authorities said on Thursday.  Kazakhstan President Kassym-Jomart Tokayev speaks during a joint news conference in Berlin, Germany, December 5, 2019. (REUTERS/Hannibal Hanschke/FILE PHOTO/MANILA BULLETIN) The Central Asian country, which borders China, has so far reported no coronavirus cases, but Kazakh authorities have said the arrival of the disease appeared imminent. The government will ensure a steady supply of food and other necessities, President Kassym-Jomart Tokayev wrote on Twitter, urging officials to minimize the impact of the pandemic on small- and medium-sized businesses. Government officials told a briefing that the spring break at schools would start a week earlier and be extended to April 5, and colleges and universities would switch to distance learning. Cinemas will also close. Kazakhstan is reducing the frequency of flights to Western European nations, the United Arab Emirates and Belarus, officials said. The Interfax news agency quoted deputy prime minister Alikhan Smailov as saying the June World Trade Organisation ministerial conference in Kazakhstan had been canceled. However, the trade and integration ministry said no decision had been made so far with regards to the WTO conference. Tags: ncov

title: Two schools in Albay suspend classes due to COVID-19
author: By Niño Luces
text: By Niño Luces  LEGAZPI CITY, Albay – St. Agnes Academy and Genecom Institute of Technology (GIT), all private schools located in this city have suspended their classes from March 13, as a precautionary measure against the coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19). In an advisory issued by St. Agnes Academy to parents, classes will be suspended from March 13 to March 25. Classes will resume on March 26, 2020. All activities are also canceled on those days, while other related educational activities are also canceled. Last Monday, Grades rade 11 and 12 students of St. Agnes Academy went on educational tour in Metro Manila and among those they visited was Senator Win Gatchalian. The school allegedly ordered the students to follow protocols and be quarantined. The Genecom Institute of Technology has ended classes since March 13. GIT said that last day of regular class is on March 13, 2020 to reduce exposure and heightened precautions. All related compliance such as submission of projects, special examinations, signing of clearance and other related matters shall be done on appointment with the teachers concerned. “Everyone is advised to avoid crowded spaces and observe proper hand washing and sanitation as our contribution to lessening the probability of virus contraction and local transmission. We ask for your understanding and cooperation for the safety and well-being of everyone. Let’s pray for one another and hope that together, we can win against this virus. Stay safe everyone,” the advisory said. Tags: ncov

title: Mayor Gatchalian also under self-quarantine
author: By Joseph Pedrajas
text: By Joseph Pedrajas Valenzuela City Mayor Rex Gatchalian is currently undergoing self-quarantine as a preventive measure against coronavirus disease (COVID-19).  Valenzuela City Mayor Rex Gatchalian (Rex Gatchalian official Facebook page / MANILA BULLETIN) Gatchalian on Thursday afternoon confirmed to Manila Bulletin that he is “already at home and undergoing self-quarantine,” taking initiative “like the other mayors.” Gatchalian disclosed this as he was also present in an event last week, where one attendee eventually tested positive for COVID-19. “I am [doing fine],” Gatchalian gave assurance. The city council of Valenzuela City is scheduled on Thursday afternoon to hold a special session where concerns on panic buying and hoarding of basic necessities will be discussed. READ MORE: List: Gov’t officials on self-quarantine due to COVID-19 exposure Tags: ncov

title: PSG: No Malacañang lockdown despite COVID-19 outbreak
author: By Argyll Cyrus Geducos
text: By Argyll Cyrus Geducos  The Presidential Security Group (PSG) maintained that the Malacañang compound will not be locked down despite reports of Cabinet members being exposed to patients who tested positive for coronavirus disease (COVID-19).  Malacañang Palace. (Photo by Richard V. Viñas / MANILA BULLETIN FILE PHOTO) In a statement, the PSG said it will disinfect and decontaminate the areas frequented by President Duterte instead of closing down the entire compound. “The Presidential Security Group (PSG) will not actually implement [a] lockdown of Malacañan Palace. Our measure is more on precautionary and preventive one against COVID-19, through disinfection and decontamination, especially in areas frequently used by President Rodrigo Roa Duterte,” they said Thursday. The PSG added that work inside Malacañang will continue despite the disinfection and decontamination, which will follow a schedule. “This is also for the welfare of all the employees, to make them feel at ease and safe while working. Employees will temporarily vacate their offices as we conduct disinfection and shall resume work after an hour,” the PSG said. “This will be done on a scheduled basis to ensure not just the safety of our President but also all of those working behind him in the seat of our government, to continuously serve the Filipino people.” President Duterte was reported to have undergone testing for COVID-19, despite not showing symptoms, because of his regular engagement with Cabinet members. Cabinet members including Transportation Secretary Arthur Tugade and Finance Secretary Carlos Dominguez opted to go on self-quarantine after being exposed to a patient who tested positive for the virus. Education Secretary Leonor Briones was also advised to go on quarantine because of her interactions with her colleagues in the Cabinet. Earlier, Communications Secretary Martin Andanar reminded employees that work-from-home arrangements in accordance with the guidelines released by the Department of Labor and Employment and the Civil Service Commission may be considered. He also appealed to the public to be “understanding and cooperative” in taking the necessary precautions and in following safety protocols. Tags: ncov

title: Iligan medical society confirms one COVID-19 patient
author: By Bonita Ermac
text: By Bonita Ermac ILIGAN CITY – The local government unit (LGU) and the Iligan Medical Society here confirmed one patient positive for coronavirus disease (COVID-19) in a press conference at the City Mayor’s Office here Thursday (March 12).  The local government unit (LGU) and the Iligan Medical Society here confirmed one patient positive for coronavirus disease (COVID-19) in a press conference at the City Mayor’s Office (Bonita Ermac / MANILA BULLETIN) The patient identified as PH40 was admitted to the Adventist Medical Center (AMC) on March 3 due to fever, cough, and shortness of breath, City Health Office (CHO) chief Dra. Cherlina Cañaveral said. PH40 is 54 years old, male, and was referred from Iligan’s AMC to the Northern Mindanao Medical Center in Cagayan de Oro City, she said. Infectious disease specialist Dr. Leonel Quitos said the patient had been suffering fever, cough, and breathing difficulty for two weeks before he was confined at AMC. The patient was referred Quitos on March 7, when PH40 was no longer responding to antibiotics. On March 8, PH40 was transported to Northern Mindanao Medical Center in Cagayan de Oro City where he was confirmed positive for COVID-19 on March 11. Dr. Quitos, per advice from NMMC doctors, said PH40 is improving and his immediate relatives are asymptomatic. Task Force COVID-19 is having difficulty tracing PH40’s contacts as he is hesitant to reveal his movements. PH40 worked in Pasig and has an office in San Juan in Manila, the epicenter of COVID-19 in the Philippines. “The DOH has protocols on how to do contact tracing. The most important thing is for the public to cooperate,” Quitos said. “Having said that. if you are questioned, it doesn’t mean that you are infected or what — it means that we are investigating,” he added. Adventist Medical Center President Dr. Edgar Nadal said some 20 healthcare workers who were in contact with PH40 were quarantined. “However, at this point, they are taken care of properly and all of them haven’t manifested any symptoms of COVID-19 virus,” Nadal said. Meanwhile, Vice Mayor Jemar Vera Cruz, through the Sangguniang Panlungsod, will conduct an emergency session on Friday (March 13) to recommend to the local chief executive to suspend all classes in Iligan City. Tags: ncov

title: Palace: China willing to aid PH in fight vs. COVID-19
author: By Genalyn Kabiling
text: By Genalyn Kabiling China is willing to extend assistance to the Philippines to battle the outbreak of the new coronavirus disease (COVID-19), Malacañang announced Thursday in the wake of the surge of infections in the country.  President Rodrigo Roa Duterte and Ambassador of the People’s Republic of China to the Philippines Huang Xilian (KING RODRIGUEZ/PRESIDENTIAL PHOTO / MANILA BULLETIN FILE PHOTO) Chinese Ambassador to the Philippines Huang Xilian made the offer after President Duterte cited Chinese President Xi Jinping’s handling of the health emergency during their meeting at the Palace last Wednesday. “President Rodrigo Roa Duterte on Wednesday received China Ambassador Huang Xilian, stressing the importance of continued economic cooperation as well as working together to addresses challenges posed by the spread of COVID-19,” a Palace press statement read. “Huang expressed solidarity with the Philippine government in its efforts to contain the spread of COVID-19. The Chinese ambassador also conveyed China’s readiness to extend assistance,” it said. In the meeting with the Chinese envoy, President Duterte also offered the country’s sympathy and solidarity with the people of China affected by the coronavirus outbreak. The government recently donated 52 boxes containing emergency medical and food supplies for the people of virus-hit Wuhan in Hubei province. “He extended the Philippines’ solidarity with China and the international community in addressing the global public health emergency,” the Palace said. “President Duterte has noted President Xi Jinping’s handling of the health emergency,” it added. The World Health Organization has recently declared the coronavirus outbreak a pandemic after it rapidly spread from Wuhan to more than 100 countries in recent weeks. The number of worldwide cases has reached more than 100,000 while the deaths have surpassed the 4,000 mark. More than 3,000 people have died due to the virus in China, mostly in Hubei province. As of Wednesday, the Philippines has recorded 49 cases of infections, including two fatalities. A public health emergency has been declared over the country to intensify efforts to contain the spread of the disease. Closer Philippines-China economic cooperation The Philippines and China have also agreed to sustain economic cooperation, including the area of infrastructure development. According to the Palace, the President recognized China’s “continued support to the socio-economic agenda of his administration.” As the two nations mark the 45th year of diplomatic relations this June, Duterte expressed hope that “China will continue to extend support and fast track infrastructure development.” “He looks forward to a more robust trade with China, with a greater and improved access for Philippine exports to the Chinese market,” the Palace said. Huang also assured the President about China’s commitment for “a deeper cooperation” with the Philippines especially in infrastructure development, according to the Palace. “He noted the steady progress in the joint infrastructure projects over the past two years,” it said. The President previously declared that the Philippines and China continue to be “two great friends” despite a lingering territorial conflict. He has pursued bilateral dialogue with China to manage the dispute in the West Philippine Sea while seeking closer economic and security ties at the start of his term. Recently, the offshore gaming operations mostly run by Chinese nationals have been under scrutiny over alleged criminal and other illegal activities. The President, however, refused to suspend or shut down these offshore gambling services, insisting they are “clean” and provide huge revenues for the government. Tags: ncov

title: ‘Better than nothing’: Thailand encourages cloth masks amid surgical mask shortage
author: By Reuters
text: By Reuters BANGKOK (Reuters) – Thailand’s health authorities are encouraging people to make cloth face masks at home to guard against the spread of the coronavirus amid a shortage of surgical masks. Thailand, which has reported a total of 70 cases, put surgical masks and sanitizers under its list of controlled goods last month, as the spread of the coronavirus led to shortages in stores. The shortage of surgical masks prompted the Thai government to approve a 225 million baht ($7 million) budget last week for government agencies to produce 50 million cloth masks in a matter of days for nationwide distribution. Cloth masks are enough to prevent people from catching the virus via droplets from coughing or sneezing, said Panpimon Wipulakorn, Director-General for the Department of Health. “The droplet from coughing and sneezing is around five microns and we have tested already that cloth masks can protect against droplets bigger than one micron,” Panpimon said, adding that the masks needed to be washed daily. The official herself appeared in a public health ministry video teaching people how to make cloth masks at home. Workshops have also been set up nationwide to help produce the masks. Many Thais answered the government’s call by getting together in small groups at community centers around the country to make masks from cloth and distribute them to others for free.
